document_metadata.name: Progressive multiple sclerosis: prospects for disease therapy, repair, and restoration of function

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Patients with primary and secondary progressive multiple sclerosis exhibit gradually worsening disability, most often motor impairment with a pattern suggesting a myelopathy, but also progressive hemiparesis, ataxia, visual dysfunction, or cognitive impairment.

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: In the early stages, pathology is dominated by focal inflammatory lesions with perivenular accumulation of T and B lymphocytes, bloodâbrain barrier disruption, demyelination, and acute axonal transection.[5]

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: The severity of cortical demyelination correlates with the extent of meningeal inflammation in progressive multiple sclerosis, suggesting a pathogenic role.[10]

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: In the early stages, pathology is dominated by focal inflammatory lesions with perivenular accumulation of T and B lymphocytes, bloodâbrain barrier disruption, demyelination, and acute axonal transection.[5]

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: The clinical importance of grey matter pathology involving cortex, deep structures, cerebellum, and spinal cord is increasingly recognised in progressive multiple sclerosis.[7]

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Cortical histopathology includes microglial activation, demyelination, neuritic transection, neuronal death, and reduced presynaptic terminals, but tends not to include perivascular lymphocytic cuffs typical of white matter lesions.[8]

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Cortical histopathology includes microglial activation, demyelination, neuritic transection, neuronal death, and reduced presynaptic terminals, but tends not to include perivascular lymphocytic cuffs typical of white matter lesions.[8]

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Demyelinated axons are abundant in longstanding multiple sclerosis and are hypothesised to be susceptible to chronic injury.[6]

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Atrophy of deep grey structures (thalamus, caudate, and hippocampus) also occurs in progressive multiple sclerosis and can be focal (presumably due to lesions) or more diffuse (presumably due to damage to afferent or efferent connections).[29,30]

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Cellular energy metabolism seems to be abnormal in progressive multiple sclerosis [11] and is another potential therapeutic target.

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: The clinical importance of grey matter pathology involving cortex, deep structures, cerebellum, and spinal cord is increasingly recognised in progressive multiple sclerosis.[7]

links.evidence: Cortical histopathology includes microglial activation, demyelination, neuritic transection, neuronal death, and reduced presynaptic terminals, but tends not to include perivascular lymphocytic cuffs typical of white matter lesions.[8]

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: The severity of cortical demyelination correlates with the extent of meningeal inflammation in progressive multiple sclerosis, suggesting a pathogenic role.[10]

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: In some demyelinated axons, saltatory nerve-impulse conduction is replaced by continuous conduction, which restores function but increases energy demand and sodium accumulation in the axonal cytoplasm. Resultant reverse operation of sodiumâcalcium exchanger to restore ionic gradients could lead to cytoplasmic calcium accumulation, activation of calpains, and proteolysis of cytoskeleton.

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Mitochondrial dysfunction in axons seems to result from impaired mitochondrial transport, susceptibility to oxidative injury, and mutations in mitochondrial DNA, all of which lead to impaired energy production and generation of reactive oxygen species.

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Whole-brain atrophy correlates with physical [20] and cognitive [21] impairment.

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Cortical atrophy is prominent in progressive multiple sclerosis [26] and correlates with physical [27] and cognitive [28] impairment.

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Whole-brain atrophy correlates with physical [20] and cognitive [21] impairment.

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Cortical atrophy is prominent in progressive multiple sclerosis [26] and correlates with physical [27] and cognitive [28] impairment.

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Spinal cord atrophy correlates with clinical measures of disability.[35]

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Fingolimod reduced relapses, MRI lesion activity, and brain volume loss in three phase 3 trials in relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis.[56â58]

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Fingolimod reduced relapses, MRI lesion activity, and brain volume loss in three phase 3 trials in relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis.[56â58]

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Fingolimod readily enters the brain and has direct effects on several CNS cell types mediated by sphingosine 1-phosphate receptors, suggesting it might be beneficial in progressive multiple sclerosis.[59]

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Fingolimod readily enters the brain and has direct effects on several CNS cell types mediated by sphingosine 1-phosphate receptors, suggesting it might be beneficial in progressive multiple sclerosis.[59]

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: The vitamin biotin is a coenzyme for many essential carboxylases and, in high doses, is hypothesised to enhance cellular energy production with resultant improved axonal function, decreased neurodegeneration, and enhanced remyelination.[65]

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: LINGO-1 is a protein expressed by oligodendrocytes and neurons that inhibits remyelination.[66]

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: A pilot study of clemastine showed improvement on visual evoked potentials in participants with multiple sclerosis-related chronic optic neuropathy.[73]

citation.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: A pilot study of clemastine showed improvement on visual evoked potentials in participants with multiple sclerosis-related chronic optic neuropathy.[73]
